sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono:
• Prior to administration, evaluate liver and thyroid function and serum creatinine, and monitor periodically during treatment.
  • Malignant melanoma, Unresectable or metastatic disease with progression following ipilimumab and a BRAF inhibitor (if BRAF V600 mutation-positive): 3 mg/kg IV infusion over 1 hour every 2 weeks until disease progression or unacceptable toxicity
  • Non-small cell lung cancer, Metastatic disease, after failure of prior platinum-based chemotherapy: 3 mg/kg IV infusion over 1 hour every 2 weeks until disease progression or unacceptable toxicity

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono: Safety and efficacy in pediatric patients not established.

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono:
• Renal toxicity, moderate to severe (grade 2 or 3), serum creatinine elevation greater than 1.5 and up to 6 times ULN or greater than 1.5 times baseline level: Administer corticosteroids and withhold treatment until resolution to grade 0 or 1; if no improvement following corticosteroid treatment, resolution to grade 0 or 1 does not occur within 12 weeks, or worsening occurs (greater than 6 times ULN), permanently discontinue.
  • Renal toxicity, life-threatening serum creatinine elevation (grade 4): Permanently discontinue.
  • Hepatic toxicity, moderate (grade 2), ALT or AST greater than 3 to up to 5 times ULN, or total bilirubin greater than 1.5 and up to 3 times ULN: Administer corticosteroids and withhold treatment until resolution to grade 0 or 1; if resolution to grade 0 or 1 does not occur within 12 weeks, permanently discontinue.
  • Hepatic toxicity, severe (grade 3 or 4), ALT or AST greater than 5 times ULN, or total bilirubin greater than 3 times ULN: Permanently discontinue.
  • Colitis, grade 2 or 3: Administer corticosteroids and withhold treatment until resolution to grade 0 or 1; if resolution to grade 0 or 1 does not occur within 12 weeks, permanently discontinue.
  • Colitis, grade 4 or for recurrent colitis upon reinitiation: Permanently discontinue.
  • Pneumonitis, grade 2: Administer corticosteroids and withhold treatment until resolution to grade 0 or 1; if resolution to grade 0 or 1 does not occur within 12 weeks, permanently discontinue.
  • Pneumonitis, grade 3 or 4: Permanently discontinue.
  • Treatment-related adverse event, grade 3 or severe: Withhold treatment until resolution to grade 0 or 1 and consider reinitiation following corticosteroid treatment, based on severity of event; if reaction does not recover to grade 1 or completely resolve within 12 weeks or if event recurs following reinitiation, permanently discontinue.

sub.title: Indications
sub.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
  • Malignant melanoma, Unresectable or metastatic disease with progression following ipilimumab and a BRAF inhibitor (if BRAF V600 mutation-positive)
  • Non-small cell lung cancer, Metastatic disease, after failure of prior platinum-based chemotherapy

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono: Specific contraindications have not been determined

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• Endocrine and Metabolic:
  • -- Immune-mediated hypothyroidism and hyperthyroidism has been reported; monitoring recommended
  • Gastrointestinal:
  • -- Immune-mediated colitis has been reported; monitoring recommended and interruption or permanent discontinuation may be necessary
  • Hepatic:
  • -- Liver enzyme (ALT, AST, or bilirubin) elevations have been reported; monitoring recommended and interruption or discontinuation may be necessary
  • -- Immune-mediated hepatitis has been reported; monitoring recommended and interruption or permanent discontinuation may be necessary
  • Immunologic:
  • -- Clinically significant immune-mediated events (eg, pancreatitis, demyelination, autoimmune neuropathy, adrenal insufficiency, nerve paresis, diabetic ketoacidosis, Guillain-Barre syndrome, myasthenic syndrome) have been reported and may occur following treatment discontinuation; therapy interruption may be necessary
  • Renal:
  • -- Immune-mediated nephritis or renal dysfunction has been reported; monitoring recommended and interruption or permanent discontinuation may be necessary for serum creatinine elevation
  • Reproductive:
  • -- Pregnancy; fetal harm may occur; women of reproductive potential should use effective contraception during therapy and for 5 or more months after discontinuation
  • Respiratory:
  • -- Severe pneumonitis or interstitial lung disease, sometimes fatal, has been reported; monitoring recommended and interruption or discontinuation may be necessary

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Dermatologic:Pruritus (11% to 19%), Rash (16% to 21%; grades 3 or 4, 0.4% to 0.9%)
  • Endocrine metabolic:Hyperkalemia (All grades, 15% to 18%; grades 3 or 4, 2% to 4.4%), Hyponatremia (All grades, 25% to 38%; grades 3 or 4, 5% to 10%)
  • Gastrointestinal:Constipation (24%), Decrease in appetite (35%; grade 3 or 4, 2.6%), Nausea (29%; grade 3 or 4, 1.7%)
  • Hepatic:Alkaline phosphatase raised (All grades, 14% to 22%; grades 3 or 4, 0% to 2.4%)
  • Musculoskeletal:Musculoskeletal pain (36%; grade 3 or 4, 6%)
  • Respiratory:Cough (17% to 32%), Upper respiratory infection (Up to 11%)
  • Other:Fatigue (50%; grade 3 or 4, 7%)
Serious
  • Cardiovascular:Vasculitis (Less than 2%)
  • Endocrine metabolic:Adrenal insufficiency (Less than 2%), Diabetic ketoacidosis, Hypercalcemia (All grades, 20%; grades 3 or 4, 2.6%), Hyperthyroidism (1.7% to 3%), Hypophysitis, Hypopituitarism, Hypothyroidism (4.3% to 8%)
  • Gastrointestinal:Colitis, Or diarrhea (21%; immune-mediated, 2.2%), Pancreatitis (Less than 2%)
  • Hepatic:ALT/SGPT level raised (All grades, 12% to 16%; grades 3 or 4, 0% to 1.6%), AST/SGOT level raised (All grades, 16% to 28%; grades 3 or 4, 0.9% to 2.4%), Hepatitis (Immune-mediated, 1.1%), Serum bilirubin raised (2.7% to 9%)
  • Musculoskeletal:Abducens nerve palsy, And facial (Less than 1%), Eaton-Lambert syndrome
  • Neurologic:Demyelination of spinal cord (Less than 2%), Guillain-Barr syndrome, Motor dysfunction (Less than 2%), Neurological muscle weakness (Less than 2%), Neuropathy, Autoimmune (Less than 2%)
  • Ophthalmic:Uveitis (Less than 2%)
  • Renal:Nephritis, Or renal dysfunction (Immune-mediated, 0.7% to 0.9%), Serum creatinine raised (13% to 22%)
  • Respiratory:Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, Exacerbation (2% or greater), Dyspnea (38%; grade 3 or 4, 9%), Hemoptysis (2% or greater), Pleural effusion (2% or greater), Pneumonia (10%; grade 3 or 4, 5%), Pneumonitis (3.4% to 6%; immune-mediated pneumonitis, 2.2%)
  • Other:Pain (10%; grade 3 or 4, 2.6%)

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Nivolumab is a monoclonal antibody that enhances the antitumor response by binding to PD-1 receptors and blocking its interaction with PD-L1 and PD-L2. In mouse models blocking PD-1 activity resulted in decreased tumor growth.

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Intravenous
  • Withdraw desired volume from vial and dilute in either NS or D5W to a final concentration of 1 to 10 mg/mL.
  • Gently invert to mix; do not shake.
  • Discard unused portions of vial.
  • Do not freeze.
  • If stored at room temperature, administer within 4 hours, including preparation and infusion time; if stored under refrigeration (2 to 8 degrees C or 36 to 46 degrees F), administer within 24 hours.
  • Infuse over 1 hour via a sterile, nonpyrogenic, low protein-binding, inline filter with a pore size of 0.2 to 1.2 mcm.
  • Do not infuse other drugs via the same IV line.
  • Flush line following infusion.

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• Reduction in tumor growth may indicate efficacy
  • Liver function tests; prior to and periodically during treatment
  • Serum creatinine levels; prior to and periodically during treatment
  • Thyroid function; prior to and periodically during treatment
  • Signs and symptoms of pneumonitis
  • Signs and symptoms of immune-mediated colitis

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Recommend patient use reliable contraception to avoid pregnancy during therapy and at least 5 months post-treatment.
  • Side effects include rash, pruritus, cough, upper respiratory tract infection, and peripheral edema.
  • Instruct patient to immediately report signs/symptoms of pneumonitis (new or worsening cough, chest pain, shortness of breath).
  • Advise patient to immediately report signs/symptoms of colitis (diarrhea or severe abdominal pain).
  • Instruct patient to immediately report signs/symptoms of hepatitis (jaundice, severe nausea or vomiting, abdominal pain on right side, lethargy, easy bruising or bleeding).
  • Inform patient to immediately report signs/symptoms of nephritis (decreased urine output, blood in urine, swelling of ankles, loss of appetite) or any other symptoms of renal dysfunction.
  • Advise patient to immediately report signs/symptoms of hypothyroidism or hyperthyroidism.
